Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 ... my local hospital chain initiated online patient access to all diagnostic studies done by them -- blood tests, X-rays, Cat Scans, MRIs, surgical pathology reports, etc. ... Yes, the irony is that the same thing is done here as this is a university hospital. I already have tons of results uploaded for all other procedures .... just this is an older surgeon who doesn't care about computers. Anyway, that is irrelevant now since I just got the results by snail mail. Here we go: FINAL DIAGNOSIS Prostatic adenocarcinoma Gleason grade 4+5 (score=9) 18mm Second focus of adenocarcinoma grade 3+3 (score=6) 8mm Bladder, 22 lymph nodes and seminal vesicles no evidence of malignancy Surgical margins with no evidence of malignancy Comment: Stage grouping II (pT2b, N0, Mx) I believe these are good news although I don't understand some of the abbreviations of the comment. The nurse also finally returned my call, the pain in my butt may last up to 6 weeks, she said. Thank you guys for your support.
Posts.Title: Wolfgang

Posts.Content: Hello comrades, I guess I am just another guy to join the club. I recently had a radical prostatectomy and I am now recovering at home. I am currently 63 and here is the timing: 10/2009 - PSA 3.6 very mild BPH symptoms 04/2010 - PSA 4.5 first TRUS biopsy, negative 10/2010 - PSA 5.6 second TRUS biopsy, negative, 04/2011 - PSA 6.7 still mild symptoms, no nocturnal peeing 10/2011 - PSA 7.8 still mild symptoms, no nocturnal peeing 10/2012 - PSA 8.9 still mild symptoms, no nocturnal peeing 12/2013 - PSA 10.7 still mild symptoms, no nocturnal peeing 04/2014 - Saturated 3D Perineal biopsy, SURPRISE! came POSITIVE! Out of 52 samples 7 cores found malignant, Gleason score between 7 and 9 05/06/2014 Classic Retro-pubic Radical Prostatectomy with Hernia repair, Seminal Vesicles and Lymph nodes removed too. 2 weeks after - Catheter removed 3 weeks after (today): The incision site pretty well healed. Incontinence is present when I get up, keeps me dry when I seat or in bed. ED, I don't even go there because of the persistent pain at the bottom. I still have not seen the post-operative Pathology results, my surgeon is a dinosaur from the Jurassic era, not skilled to upload results to my online account. He doesn't even give a damn to return messages I sent on line. I read the best things about him before the surgery but he never showed up to visit me after. The nurse said the results were good, still expecting to be mailed. Now, my concern, I have severe pain in the Perineum (the area between the scrotum and the anus). The pain extends to my left leg and I feel pain when I get up and walk. The pain is somewhat tolerable but not totally gone with Percocet. No fever or high body temperature but still not comfortable with my situation. Any comments appreciated.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> I am currently 63 and here is the timing

Posts.Title: Wolfgang

Posts.Content: Thank you guys for your heartwarming welcome to the forum. You seem to be more concerned about my health than my health provider whose job is to do so. All I get is voice mail when I try to get the nurse on the phone and she almost never returns the calls. And at this hospital they considered to be one of the top hospitals in the U.S. Anyway, I forgot to mention in my original post that my CT and bone scans were done after the last biopsy and they were negative. It was some kind of relief after getting the first pathology results with most Gleason scores to be 9. I am still expecting the final pathology results to see more details. Will keep you posted as soon as I get them. P.S. Thanks for moving this thread to the right forum, I kind of followed the link to place my first post without thinking where was going to be posted.

Posts.Title: Wolfgang

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Leob Hi I was told last week that I have a hernia on my left side ....... ... in terms of difficulties concerning future prostate removal? In my case, I had hernia for several years and when I told that to my surgeon prior to prostatectomy, he said he would take care for both the hernia and prostate at the same time. So he did it and I had my hernia repaired during my prostate removal surgery. Two birds with one stone.
Posts.Title: Effect of type of hernia operation on future prostate removal (laparoscopic ver open)

Posts.Content: After my prostatectomy I got severe Urinary Tract Infection (via the catheter I guess). I told the nurse I had severe pain (the doc was never accessible) and she said it is normal to have pain after the surgery up to 6 weeks so I suffered the pain until the follow-up. When I told my surgeon I still have severe pain and can't even walk normally he was surprised. They took a urine sample and the test results were ready the same day on line. My urine culture showed >100,000 CFU/mL Klebsiella pneumoniae. I got 14 pills of antibiotics (Ciprofloxacin) for one week only. I will have a new urine test one week after using all the pills to see if I will get rid of the infection. I must say the pain has reduced significantly during the week I was taking the pills but I was wondering if one week treatment is enough for such severe infection I had that totally slowed down my post surgery recovery. Has anyone had such an experience with urinary infection and what dose of antibiotics has resolved the condition?
Posts.Signature: Age 63 in 2014 10/2009 - PSA 3.6 Mild BPH symptoms 04/2010 - PSA 4.5 First TRUS biopsy, negative 10/2010 - PSA 5.6 Second TRUS biopsy, negative, 12/2013 - PSA 10.7 Mild symptoms, no nocturia 04/2014 - Saturated biopsy, 7/52 , Gleason 4+5 05/2014 - Retropubic Radical Prostatectomy w/ Hernia repair Post-Op - Pathology negative, PCa Stage pT2b, N0, Mx 06/2014 - Incontinence, ED still present 06/2014 - PSA Total Ultra-sensitive <0.01
Posts.Title: Still Fighting Infection after Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: @Bravehardon - I also felt better after a few pills and now a week after taking Ciprofloxacin I feel maybe 75% cured but I am afraid it'll take some more pills and time to get rid of this pest. @Otago - You are right but I learned that the hard way. Now when I need something, I just show up at the front desk, no more pointless phone calls
Posts.Signature: Age 63 in 2014 10/2009 - PSA 3.6 Mild BPH symptoms 04/2010 - PSA 4.5 First TRUS biopsy, negative 10/2010 - PSA 5.6 Second TRUS biopsy, negative, 12/2013 - PSA 10.7 Mild symptoms, no nocturia 04/2014 - Saturated biopsy, 7/52 , Gleason 4+5 05/2014 - Retropubic Radical Prostatectomy w/ Hernia repair Post-Op - Pathology negative, PCa Stage pT2b, N0, Mx 06/2014 - Incontinence, ED still present 06/2014 - PSA Total Ultra-sensitive <0.01
Posts.Title: Still Fighting Infection after Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Yes, I do have access to other clinics and doctors. This is the Urology-Oncology clinic at the University Hospital where I had the surgery and I felt I was going to stick around for a while for all these follow-ups regarding the PSA and such but I see now that it is not in my best interest to keep going there. I was very satisfied with my urologist that performed the biopsy and discovered the PCa but he was doing only Cryotherapy of prostate and he referred me to the Oncology clinic's surgeon for the RP within the same hospital. Maybe I should return back to him, he was at least answering his messages online after all.
Posts.Title: Still Fighting Infection after Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Well, this is going to be really tough. Is the nurse practitioner going to accept my suggestions that she doesn't know what she is doing although I know she doesn't? I am sick of this hospital where they think they are one of the best in the US. Yeah right, they might be one of the worst.

Posts.Title: Still Fighting Infection after Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Moo I want to see other comments. Please advise me. Is it possible to conclude that from the results are pretty obvious I have cancer? I am really sorry to hear that your PSA number has elevated after the prostate surgery. The PSA findings in the blood may come from prostate tumors only. The abbreviation comes from Prostate Specific Antigen so your blood test results indicate that some leftovers from the originating tumor are still releasing such antigens in your blood. Only special tests like biopsy or imaging may detect now what exactly is going on in your body and to what extent your PCa has spread. The initial tests that detected the existing PCa that led to your prostatectomy were very important to tell the surgeon what had to be removed at the time of the surgery. My biopsy results were devastating, I had most aggressive malignant tumor in my prostate (Gleason score 4+5) which required immediate radical prostatectomy and everything around that might be affected with such an aggressive tumor. Besides the prostate and seminal vesicles, they had removed 22 lymph nodes. Everything removed was sent to detailed pathology examining in order to categorize the PCa stage and to anticipate the further healing process. You lack of more detailed tests, what was found and what was expected in future. I hope that after more tests are done you'll have more clear picture what options you have toward your healing. Right now without those test results it is difficult to say what are those options, even for more educated person as your doctor is.
Posts.Signature: Age 63 in 2014 10/2009 - PSA 3.6 Mild BPH symptoms 04/2010 - PSA 4.5 First TRUS biopsy, negative 10/2010 - PSA 5.6 Second TRUS biopsy, negative, 12/2013 - PSA 10.7 Mild symptoms, no nocturia 04/2014 - Saturated biopsy, 7/52 , Gleason 4+5 05/2014 - Retropubic Radical Prostatectomy w/ Hernia repair Post-Op - Pathology negative, PCa Stage pT2b, N0, Mx 06/2014 - Incontinence, ED still present 06/2014 - PSA Total Ultra-sensitive <0.01

Posts.Title: PSA 35 2 year after prostate surgery

Posts.Content: The information thanks to the internet is available equally to everyone that has internet access i.e. you. We tried to explain some of the medical terms based on our experience but it is up to you to continue to search for alternative medicine that was known way before 1940. In cases like your father the docs can't do much except to empty your pockets. They did diagnose him and you have the latest technology scans which means your (still unknown) country is not much behind the western world. We are not doctors and we can't ask our doctors what would be the best treatment for your father. I wish him good luck with his hormone treatment.
Posts.Title: The emergency Question about Diphereline

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FeatherBoy ... Prostate 5LX is is just another saw palmetto product designed to be used for relief of benign conditions of the prostate ... While the above is true, the Saw Palmetto does not reduce the PSA levels. I was taking high dose Saw Palmetto 1000 mg capsules for about 3 years and while my BPH symptoms were mild, my PSA level tripled in that period of time. It certainly shrunk the gland which was verified by the urologist who performed the first TRUS (unfortunately false negative) biopsies. I then realized it was about time to get saturation biopsy to detect the suspecting cancer in my prostate.

And yes, I am a Motorola guy, worked 15 years on cellular phones and currently on digital cable TV boxes. I am wondering what has left from Motorola now, LOL.
Posts.Title: Ductal adenocarcinoma of the prostate

Posts.Content: I found some more on this at the Department of Pathology, The Johns Hopkins Medical Institutions, Baltimore, Maryland, USA. "Ductal adenocarcinoma of the prostate, previously referred to as endometrioid cancer, is typically diagnosed on transurethral resection. When treated by radical prostatectomy (RP), it pursues a more aggressive clinical course than usual acinar prostate cancer does. The significance of prostate cancer with ductal features found on needle biopsies from the peripheral zone is unknown. We reviewed 58 prostate needle biopsy cases with ductal adenocarcinoma for which we were able to obtain clinical information. Patients had a mean age of 69 years (range, 50-89 years) and had a wide range of levels of serum prostate-specific antigen (median, 7.9 ng/mL) and clinical stages. Six (10%) had metastases at the time of diagnosis. Cribriform or papillary structures or a mixture of the two patterns were seen in 86% of cases, whereas in the remaining cases, discrete glands composed of tall columnar cells were present. Stromal fibrosis accompanied the ductal carcinoma in 67% of the cases. A coexisting acinar carcinoma component was identified in 48% of the biopsy specimens. On biopsy, the ductal component composed a mean of 82% of the tumor. Of the 20 tumors treated by RP, 63% had extraprostatic spread of tumor and 20% had positive margins. Two (10%) cases showed seminal vesicle invasion, but none had lymph node metastases. The number of positive needle cores correlated with RP margin status (p<0.004) and with likelihood of clinical progression (p<0.02), but not with organ-confined status. Tumor volume calculated on the 11 extensively sampled RPs ranged from 0.15 cm3 to 20.3 mL (mean, 2.8 cm3). Two years after therapy, the actuarial risk of progression was between 34% (RP patients) and 42% (all patients). A shortened average time to progression was observed relative to a previous study group of men with acinar carcinoma. Serum prostate-specific antigen levels correlated with neither RP organ-confined status nor tumor volume. We conclude that prostatic ductal adenocarcinoma seen on needle biopsy implies more advanced cancer with a shortened time to progression."

Posts.Title: Ductal adenocarcinoma of the prostate

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mikem350 ... The hormones are very tolerable so far, just some minor effects ... I am glad your hormone therapy is working well. Although I do work on Motorola equipment (besides other manufacturers) I am not a Motorola employee. I do work for a third party company currently contracting for Comcast. Our company doesn't have any early retirement plans and all I could have was a severance packet last month if I left. Going back to work in a week scares the sh!t out of me, I still take Percocet to kill the pain and have several pads changed daily due to incontinence. I simply can't stand on my feet longer than 30 min without increasing pain in my perineum/inner thigh. There is some progress though but in a week I don't think I am going to be ready to go back to work

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mom2two My dad recently had a positive biopsy. Today he had a CT scan....and will get those results on thurs. I am very scared and hoping for some encouragement ... Hi and sorry you had to be here. There is no need for panic, I know it's easier said than done but it's good that your dad went for biopsy. After your dad's CT scan (and possibly bone scan) you will have a better picture of what's going on. The scans (and his age) will determine the further treatment of the disease. Stick around and let us know the results. Good luck.

Posts.Title: I need some support...

Posts.Content: Your father's dilemma will resolve in a few days. Whether to go for radical surgery or radiation therapy depends on several factors. - Hypertension and high cholesterol don't count if controlled (I do have both) - The age of the patient: the sixties are still acceptable for a surgery - The preliminary stage of PCa based on the Gleason score, body scans (main factor) It is normal to ask for a second opinion but after you have your father's CT and bone scans done. No doctor will perform a radical prostate surgery if the tumor has metastasized, hopefully your father's scans would come out negative. Also you father's Gleason score is something not to neglect, prostatectomy is usually recommended for such a score. I wish the best of luck to your dad!

Posts.Title: Ductal adenocarcinoma of the prostate

Posts.Content: Congrats from me too. The undetectable (zero) level depends on the lab test equipment sensitivity. It is less than 0.1 (<0.1) in some cases or less than 0.01 (<0.01) in ultra sensitive lab tests. It after all depends on the clinic where they perform you PSA lab work. I had different PSA test results at two different clinic labs within very short time. My new urologist did not trust mu previous PSA test results and had ordered a new PSA test in their lab which turned out to be different. It's all <0.01 now

Posts.Title: The "Almost Zero Club" ?

Posts.Content: During my PSA monitoring period from 3.6 to 10.7 in the period of 5 years until I was diagnosed with PCa I was taking highly concentrated Saw Palmetto capsules of 1000 mg each. I don't know if that worsened (accelerated) my final Gleason Score to 9 or it helped keeping the tumor within the capsule successfully as it turned out after the prostatectomy but I know it shrunk the gland eventually and my symptoms were very mild. That gave me probably false sens of safety but who knows what exactly was the Saw Palmetto effect, positive or negative. I will never know. It is even more dificult to say what would be the effect of Saw Palmetto after a radical prostatectomy when PSA rises due to tumor spreading to other parts of the body.

Posts.Title: Post op PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Have-None ... the Biopsy 18 cores 12 cores on Right side where the MRI showed the lesions 6 cores on Left The 12 cores on Right all Gleason 7 4+3 from 40 to 95% involvement. 6 core on the left all benign .... Hi and welcome to the forum, yet this is a place no one comes by choice. I had Saturation Transperineal Biopsy with totaling 52 samples out of which 7 came positive, some of them Gleason 7 and some of them Gleason 9. The surgeon wanted me to wait about 2 months before the surgery but he didn't say the reason was the biopsy. He wanted me to start a hormone therapy to shrink the tumor. It turned out he couldn't even notice prostate enlargement by performing a DRE. I told him I might not have health coverage after 2 months due to my company's work reduction in effect and I wanted to do the surgery ASAP. So it happened, I had Retropubic Radical Prostatectomy (classic open surgery) only one month after the Saturated Biopsy. It's been over 4 weeks now after the surgery and here is the outcome: -Final pathology results encouraging, no malignancy found in any tissue removed (except the prostate) -Urinary incontinence still present, dry in horizontal position though -ED still present, sometimes enlarged size but not enough for penetration -Pain in the perineum area where the biopsy was performed still present, extends to my left inner thigh, still must take pain killers, can't seat on the butt without a soft pillow I believe your case is not so urgent as mine was, so waiting 2 months before the surgery should not do any harm. My case was somehow extreme I think.

My case was somehow extreme I think.
